awd_titl_txt: Formation and Evolution of Atmospheric Brown Carbon from Nitrate Radical Initiated Oxidation of Heterocyclic Volatile Organic Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
Brown carbon (BrC) particles in biomass burning plumes affect climate through their interaction with radiation and Earth’s energy budget, yet, little is known about their formation and radiative characteristics. In this multi-PI project, atmospheric formation and transformation processes of BrC particles are studied in systematic laboratory experiments using sophisticated analytical tools. Resulting new mechanistic information will aid in the interpretation of field observations and inform predictive climate models.
 
The project aims at increasing understanding of mechanisms of atmospheric oxidation of heterocyclic volatile organic carbons (VOCs) as sources of brown carbon (BrC) secondary organic aerosols (SOA). Systematic laboratory chamber and flow reactor experiments will be carried out that mimic nighttime conditions in which relevant VOCs are oxidized initially with nitrate radical (NO3) and subsequently aged diurnally with NO3 and hydroxyl (OH) radicals. A suite of on- and off-line state-of-the-art instruments will be employed to characterize particles’ physical and chemical properties, including size, optical parameters, molecular composition, and functional groups. In addition, a multiphase kinetic model will be developed with the data obtained from compositional measurements. The outcome of this work will aid in the interpretation of observations made in complex real biomass burning systems and provide fundamental mechanistic information that can be incorporated into larger scale climate models. Three graduate students will carry out the bulk of the laboratory work, and a number of undergraduate students from underrepresented populations will be recruited from existing programs on the PIs campus. Outreach activities include engagement with local high schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Heterocyclic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) represent a class of understudied reactive hydrocarbons emitted into the Earth's atmosphere from both natural and anthropogenic combustion sources. Recent field studies have reported observations of enhanced brown carbon (BrC) formation in biomass burning plumes through nighttime atmospheric processing. However, how heterocyclic VOCs contribute to the nighttime BrC secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation has not been fully investigated. This project combined experimental and modelling efforts to investigate the formation and evolution processes controlling chemical and optical properties of BrC SOA derived from the nighttime oxidation of atmospherically relevant heterocyclic VOCs. We utilized a suite of state-of-the-art instrumentation to measure the chemical and optical properties of BrC SOA produced under various environmental conditions. BrC SOA was characterized based on aerosol sizes, bulk and molecular compositions, functional groups, and optical properties (e.g., scattering and absorption) using complementary online and offline techniques. These properties were used to monitor changes in molecular chromophores and to explain the effects of further atmospheric processing on aerosol browning or bleaching.

Overall, the results of this research project demonstrate that nighttime oxidation of wildfire-sourced heterocyclic VOCs, particularly pyrroles, is an important precursor to the formation of BrC SOA, whereas structural differences between pyrrole and its methyl derivatives have significant implications for the optical properties of their SOA following nighttime oxidation. Our findings also reveal that several environmental factors, such as nitrate radical levels, the presence and absence of pre-existing particles, and relative humidity, all play an important role in regulating the chemical composition and optical properties of BrC SOA resulting from the nighttime oxidation of heterocyclic VOCs. Furthermore, by characterizing the carbonyl chromophores in BrC SOA in our study systems, our findings contribute to an improved understanding of chromophore formation and provide a molecular-level foundation for future research linking the chemical composition and optical properties of BrC aerosols.

Given the increasing trend of biomass burning emissions in populated (e.g., western US, India, and China) and climate sensitive regions (e.g., Canada and Alaska), significant abundance of heterocyclic VOCs in biomass burning emissions, and incomplete understanding of the nighttime production and fate of BrC SOA, results from this project have implications for providing important parameters to be represented in air quality and climate models, as well as improving the accuracy of model simulations.

Throughout the project, we incorporated our research findings into undergraduate and graduate-level atmospheric science and analytical chemistry courses, as well as providing research, networking, and educational outreach opportunities to train the next generation of STEM leaders, which included graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral scholars. This joint effort not only enhances their academic experience, but it also builds a network of informed advocates who can effectively communicate the significance of research findings to the wider community.
